articles.headline: Labor Scrutiny for FIFA as a World Cup Rises in the Qatar Desert
articles.snippet: A report last year found that migrant workers, many hired to build World Cup sites in Qatar, work under conditions akin to indentured servitude.
articles.abstract: A report last year found that migrant workers, many hired to build World Cup sites in Qatar, work under conditions akin to indentured servitude.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a law firm hired by Qatar, the site of the 2022 World Cup, issued a report last year urging reforms in the treatment of migrant construction workers there, human rights groups expected the tiny oil-rich Persian Gulf nation to respond quickly.

articles.headline: Netflix Posts Mixed Results, but New Memberships Surge
articles.snippet: Revenue was up and profits down in the second quarter, but the number of new streaming members hits a record.
articles.abstract: Revenue was up and profits down in the second quarter, but the number of new streaming members hits a record.
articles.lead_paragraph: These are heady times for Netflix.

articles.headline: Specialty Pharmacies Proliferate, Along With Questions
articles.snippet: Dispensaries for expensive drugs that treat complex or rare diseases are surging, but their customer service and business practices are under scrutiny.
articles.abstract: Dispensaries for expensive drugs that treat complex or rare diseases are surging, but their customer service and business practices are under scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINKING SPRING, Pa. — As the end of each month nears, Megan Short frets. Her 1-year-old daughter, Willow, cannot afford to miss even a single dose of a drug she takes daily to prevent her body from rejecting her transplanted heart.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: Clearing Hurdles to Iran Nuclear Deal With Standoffs, Shouts and Compromise
articles.snippet: Over a period of years, American and Iranian negotiators came to understand what mattered most to each other. Then a brief alignment of personalities and events helped bring a deal to completion.
articles.abstract: Over a period of years, American and Iranian negotiators came to understand what mattered most to each other. Then a brief alignment of personalities and events helped bring a deal to completion.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — One by one, the roadblocks to a nuclear accord between Iran and the United States had been painstakingly cleared. But as the negotiations went into their third week in the neoclassical Coburg Palace hotel this month, a major dispute lingered over whether a ban on Iran’s ability to purchase conventional weapons and missile technology would remain in place.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Lags in Engaging Grass-Roots Donors
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign has been slow to harness the fund-raising power of the Democratic Party’s legions of grass-roots donors, according to reports filed Wednesday, a weakness that her campaign is racing to combat.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign has been slow to harness the fund-raising power of the Democratic Party’s legions of grass-roots donors, according to reports filed Wednesday, a weakness that her campaign is racing to combat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign has been slow to harness the fund-raising power of the Democratic Party’s legions of grass-roots donors, according to reports filed Wednesday, a weakness that her campaign is racing to combat.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Japan Moves to Allow Military Combat for First Time in 70 Years
articles.snippet: The lawmakers endorsed Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s legislation despite broad public opposition and the largest demonstrations in three years.
articles.abstract: The lawmakers endorsed Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s legislation despite broad public opposition and the largest demonstrations in three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Defying broad public opposition and large demonstrations, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe won a crucial vote in Parliament on Thursday for legislation that would give Japan’s military limited powers to fight in foreign conflicts for the first time since World War II.

articles.headline: Obama, in Oklahoma, Takes Reform Message to the Prison Cell Block
articles.snippet: The president is intent on improving life behind bars. To make his points, he became the first sitting president to pay a visit to a federal prison.
articles.abstract: The president is intent on improving life behind bars. To make his points, he became the first sitting president to pay a visit to a federal prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL RENO, Okla. — They opened the door to Cell 123, and President Obama stared inside. In the space of 9 feet by 10 feet, he saw three bunks, a toilet with no seat, a night table with books, a small sink, prison clothes on a hook, some metal cabinets and the life he might have had.

articles.headline: WikiLeaks Shows a Saudi Obsession With Iran
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia’s alarm over the nuclear deal comes after a trove of documents revealed its efforts in recent years to undermine its primary adversary: Shiite Iran.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia’s alarm over the nuclear deal comes after a trove of documents revealed its efforts in recent years to undermine its primary adversary: Shiite Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For decades, Saudi Arabia has poured billions of its oil dollars into sympathetic Islamic organizations around the world, quietly practicing checkbook diplomacy to advance its agenda.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Mayy El Sheikh

articles.headline: Germany’s Tone Grows Sharper in Greek Debt Crisis
articles.snippet: In negotiating a new deal this week to bail out Greece, Germany displayed what many Europeans saw as a harder, more selfish edge.
articles.abstract: In negotiating a new deal this week to bail out Greece, Germany displayed what many Europeans saw as a harder, more selfish edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Despite bitter opposition in many quarters to the austerity-first policies Germany has imposed on Europe’s poorer nations, Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government has hung on to its role as champion of integration on the Continent through deft use of diplomacy and the country’s economic clout.
